is a city located approximately 420 kilometres (260 mi) north-east of
in the Côte-Nord region of the province of

. It is located on the shores of the Saint Lawrence River near the mouth of the Manicouagan River, and is the seat of Manicouagan Regional County Municipality. There are two urban area population centres within the city limits: Baie-Comeau proper, with a population of 9,917, and Hauterive, with a population of 11,844, as of the Canada 2011 Census. The total population is 22,113.

Baie-Comeau itself (the eastern part of the current town) was founded in 1936 when a paper mill was constructed by Colonel Robert R. McCormick, publisher of the Chicago Tribune. Experiencing remarkable growth, the Town of Baie-Comeau was incorporated the following year. The area continued to see economic development with the establishment of the hydro-electric power stations on the Manicouagan and Outardes Rivers beginning with the Chutes-aux-Outardes Station in 1952, an aluminum smelter in 1958, and grain warehouses (the largest in Canada) in 1959.

In July, the average daily high is near 21°C (70°F) but at night it cools down to a temperature near 10°C (50°F).
In January, the average daily high is about -9°C (16°F) but at night it cools down to a temperature near -20°C (-4°F).
No matter when in the year you go, you should always bring a jacket. Temperatures can deviate significantly from the average, so be prepared.

To get to Baie Comeau, the main option is to come by car.

From

, take Autoroute 40-E or Autoroute 20-E. If taking Autoroute 20-E you have to get onto Autoroute 40-E in Quebec City. If taking Autoroute 40-E, in Trois Rivières, take exit 196S to merge onto Autoroute 40-E/Autoroute 55-S, then take exit 182 to merge onto Autoroute 40-E. When Autoroute 40-E ends, just go straight until it becomes Autoroute 440-E which will become Quebec Route 138. Drive about 400 km until you arrive in Baie-Comeau.

From

, take Autoroute 50-E. Take exit 292S to merge onto Autoroute 15 S/Trans-Canada Hwy toward Montreal. Take exit 20 to merge onto Autoroute 640-E toward Quebec City. Take exit 52E to merge onto Autoroute 40-E toward Quebec City.  Take exit 196S to merge onto Autoroute 40-E/Autoroute 55-S toward Trois-Rivières/Centre-Ville/Quebec City. Take exit 182 to merge onto Autoroute 40-E toward Trois Rivières/Centre Ville/Quebec City. Take exit 307N for Autoroute 73 N/Autoroute 40 E/Autoroute Henri IV N toward Seguenay/Sainte Anne de Beaupré. Take exit 142E for Autoroute 40-E/Autoroute 73-N toward Saguenay/Sainte Anne de Beaupré. Go straight onto Autoroute Dufferin-Montmorency N/Autoroute 440-E until it becomes Quebec Route 138. Drive about 400 km until you arrive in Baie-Comeau.

From

, take Autoroute 440-E until it becomes Quebec Route 138. Drive about 400 km until you arrive in Baie Comeau.

From

, go to Chicoutimi Nord, where you can take Quebec Route 172-E. When you arrive at Quebec Route 138. Turn left. From there, drive about 200 km until you arrive in Baie-Comeau.

Baie-Comeau is
about 8 hours from Montreal,
about 5–6 hours from Quebec City,
about 9–10 hours from Gatineau,
and about 4 hours from Saguenay.
Domestic flights leave from Montreal and Quebec City.

value: . Buses leave from Montreal at around 6AM and from Quebec City at around 9:15AM and arrive around 4:45PM.

From Matane, take the ferry to Baie Comeau.
It's best to have a car to drive around since the two parts of Baie Comeau are separate. Walking may be reasonable depending on the distance and season.

value: content=Carole Caron paints on fabric with acrylic resin. Her works mostly feature colourful and lively scenes of children.

content=This forest learning centre allows visitors to discover the effects glaciers had on the Cote Nord region and its landscapes. Other attractions and activities include a natural park, observation sites, hiking trails and more.
content=Visitors will discover and learn about the fauna or wildlife of the Cote-Nord region. Children under the age of seven get in free. Hiking trails and a boutique are also available.
content=Constructed in 1992, the theatre can accommodate 850 guests and showcases a variety of plays and shows during the year. Ticket packages are available.

content=Côte-Nord – Manicouagan and Côte-Nord – Duplessis border the St. Lawrence for 1250 kilometres (775 miles), from Tadoussac to Blanc-Sablon. The coastline of these regions has been designated the Whale Route, since 13 different species, including the blue whale, can be found in the waters of the Estuary and Gulf of St. Lawrence.
content=There are over 50 stores and boutiques at this shopping mall in Baie-Comeau. A renovated food-fair offers a non-smoking environment. Open daily.
address= (West) 861, boulevard Lafleche, (East) 38 Place LaSalle G5C 1C7

content=Casual dining and an impressive selection of fresh sushi rolls, combination platters and signature dishes are served up at this restaurant, which offers locations in the eastern and western sectors of the city.
content=There are a variety of authentic Greek specialties at this restaurant. The menu features moussaka, spanakopita, tzatziki and more Greek foods.

content=A menu of crepes, French toast, pancakes, waffles, omelettes and eggs benny - all served with fresh fruit, have made Chez Cora a popular breakfast and brunch option. Lunchtime dishes such as soups, salads, sandwiches and quiche are also available.
name=Restaurant Bar Terrasse Les Trois Barils

content=This restaurant has a varied menu consisting of Canadian, Italian and regional specialties. Steak and seafood dishes also popular. Dining accommodations for up to 175 guests including a terrace.
content=This restaurant serves flavourful fried chicken. The chicken is tender and seasoned.
content=Guests can enjoy a fine-dining experience and sample regional dishes. The restaurant is licensed and includes a non-smoking section.
content=Enjoy pizza and fresh stuffed pastas from this restaurant. Delivery is available.
content=The restaurant features an Asian menu of fine-cuisine including seafood specialties. The location is licensed and provides non-smoking sections for its patrons.
content=Menu includes several types of pizza as well as other dishes such as pasta, salads, sandwiches and Chinese food. The restaurant is also licensed and is open late on weekends.

content=Three-star complex that was completely renovated. Has forty-five rooms, some with kitchenettes.

content=100 guest rooms, all equipped with coffee makers, cable TV, free wireless Internet access, refrigerators and microwaves. The hotel also offers free hot breakfast, a restaurant and bar, a fitness room and outdoor hot tubs. This is a pet-friendly property.

content=Hotel accommodations include 57 rooms with many amenities including free coffee, an iron and ironing board, hair dryer, telephone with alarm clock and more. Services include tennis court, bicycle and snowmobile rentals, restaurant and business centre.
content=Meeting rooms are supplied with audio and visual equipment.
content=Only hotel on the north shore with an indoor swimming pool (open July and August). Outdoor terrace and sauna adjacent to the pool.
content=The motel includes 20 rooms with both smoking and non-smoking units available. All rooms include a bathroom, television and telephone. Free outdoor parking is provided.
content=Accommodations include 14 air-conditioned rooms, each complete with private bathroom, telephone and television.
content=All rooms include amenities such as a hair dryer, clock radio and free coffee. Select suites provide additional features including Internet access and whirlpools.
